questionnaireInfo.text:
Welcome to the PhDnet Survey 2020,

 

and thank you for participating!

This is a survey for all doctoral researchers working within the Max Planck Society (MPS).

The aim of this survey is to provide a clear picture of the current payment and working conditions; the quality of the supervision and scientific practice; and the family plans of doctoral researchers at the MPS. 

This survey is voluntary and the data you are providing is evaluated in anonymized form according to the General Works Agreement - Online Employee Survey as found in the OHB (to read in detail, click here). Only aggregated and anonymized data will be shared with the administrative bodies of the centers/institutes and the public in the form of reports. Moreover, doctoral researchers' representatives can request an aggregated report for their center/institute. Your information and data will be treated confidentially and will only be accessible to the members of the Survey Group.

The survey is hosted on the MPS servers, employing the software solution LimeSurvey. If you decide to stop your participation in the middle of the survey, your collected data will be deleted at the end of the survey participation deadline. 

In order for the survey to be representative, it is vital that the majority of doctoral researchers participate and don't give mock answers. The questionnaire will take about 30 minutes to complete and contains questions about payment, working and living conditions, supervision, career, and family plans. 

If you have any questions, or wish to report technical issues, you can reach us at survey.group@phdnet.mpg.de.

 

By clicking 'Next', you agree to have read the conditions listed above, including the use of the provided data in case you complete the survey.

Thank you very much for your participation in the 2020 survey!

The data of the survey is invaluable for the realistic assessment of the situation of doctoral researchers in the Max Planck Society and the basis for future improvement for their situation. We will carefully analyse the results after the survey closes and will publish the aggregated survey results in the form of a public report as soon as they are available. 

For any questions, comments and concerns, you are welcome to contact us via email, as well as our social network platforms (Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn). You can also find us on the PhDnet homepage or by getting in touch with the PhD representatives at your center/institute.

To get a better picture on the diversity of the Max Planck Society we’re asking questions regarding to your ethnicity. Please select the option(s) that you feel best represents you. We hope this can shed light on issues certain groups could be facing within the MPS.
Please be assured that your data will be treated confidentially and used in an ethical way.

question.text: When did you start your PhD?

directive.text: The start of your doctoral research is either the start of your contract/stipend or your enrollment in a university as a doctoral researcher, whichever is earlier.

question.text: When do you expect to submit your PhD thesis?

directive.text: This is not the formal date stated in your contract or stipend, but the actual date you expect to submit. Please make your best possible estimation, if you are unsure about the right month, choose around the time you think is most likely.

question.text: Anything regarding this section you would like to tell us?

sectionInfo.text:
In this section, we ask you about your salary or income, possible contract extensions, your working hours or the amount of holidays that are entitled to you.

Section 2/8

question.text: How is your doctoral research currently financed (multiple answers possible)?

directive.text:
Explanation: A contract is usually paid according to the TVöD system (e.g. 50% or 65%) and also includes the Doktoranden Fördervertrag (support contract). With a contract you are legally bound to your workplace and pay into the social security system.  With a stipend you are not legally bound to your workplace and do not pay into the social security system.

 

To understand the difference between Doktoranden Fördervertrag and TVöD:

  Doktoranden Fördervertrag TVöD     Title Support Contract/ "Doktoranden Fördervertrag" Collective Agreement for the Public Service (TVöD) / "Tarifvertrag für den öffentlichen Dienst (TVöD     Structure Only "based on" 50% of pay group 13 TVöD ("Bezahlung ist an den TVöD 13 angelehnt") Actual pay group 13 TVöD contract ("Entgeltgruppe 13 TVöD")    

Working hours per week

39 hours/week regardless of the % payment of TVöD13 this contract is based on.

Ergo: % working hours and % payment may not be aligned.

Depends on % stated in this TVöD 13 contract. Example: if 50% of TVöD 13 = 19.5 hours/week

Ergo: % working hours and % payment are aligned.

    Salary Usually 50% of the salary of TVöD 13. Hiring bonus possible (e.g. you may receive 65% of the salary stated in TVöD 13) Depends on % stated in this TVöD 13 contract.     

Level/Stufe

Maximum 2: 

1st year = level 1

2nd year - end of PhD = level 2

No maximum: 

1st ear = level 1

2nd & 3rd year = level 2

4th - 6th year = level 3

    Annual bonus / Jahressonderzahlung Yes, entitled to it Yes, entitled to it     Entitled vacation days/year 30 (until 2019, this was only 20 days/year) 30

category.label: I don't want to answer this question

question.text: Were you aware of the difference between a Doktoranden Fördervertrag(support contract) and the actual TVöD before reading this explanation/question?

category.label: I don't want to answer this question

question.text: What kind of contract do you have? If you have multiple contracts, please select 'other' and give details.

directive.text: See explanation at B1.

category.label: I don't want to answer this question

question.text: Right now, what is your monthly net income for your work at your research organization?

directive.text:
Net income is the amount of money transferred to your bank account every month. Do not count any bonuses such as a Christmas bonus etc.

Scholarship holders and freelancers: deduct tax and health insurance.

Income not related to work in the institute/doctoral research should not be included.

category.label: I don't want to answer this question

question.text: Do you know what is being deducted from your pay slip?

directive.text: e.g. Difference from Brutto to Netto.

question.text: Over the course of your PhD have you ever received external fundings (funding outside of the MPS) as your main source of income?

directive.text:
External funding: stipend or contract NOT from the MPS for your PhD work, e.g. external funding organizations, your University, another supervisor, etc. This does not include side jobs and/or finance from family and friends to support you during your PhD.

Here is an example: The first two years of your PhD you had a contract from a University and a guest contract at your MPI, from the 3rd year on you had a contract from your MPI. In this case you would click 'Yes, in the past'.

category.label: I don't want to answer this question

question.text: What was or is the duration of your longest contract or stipend related to your PhD project?

directive.text:
For example:
1) if you got a 3 year contract in your first year, followed by a 1 year contract in your fourth year, the duration of your longest contract is 36 months.
2) if you have received 1 year contracts and extensions your whole PhD, the duration of your longest contract is 12 months.
3) if you are currently at the end of your first year on a contract that runs for 36 months in total, your longest contract is 36 months.

category.label: I don’t want to answer this question

category.label: I did not get any extensions or additional contracts/stipends

directive.text: Working time - that is both for your dissertation and all other tasks you have to perform at your institute or university, for instance project work or meetings (in your office as well as at other places) and teaching.

sectionInfo.text:
In this section, we ask questions about how satisfied you are with different aspects of your work as a doctoral researcher, e.g. which of them could be improved, what you think about a career in academia, and if you have ever considered quitting your PhD. 

Section 3/8

question.text: If you think about your own situation as a doctoral researcher, how satisfied are you with the following aspects?

subQuestion.text: COVID-19 situation handling at your institute
Health management facilities/ physical health courses/ physical health activities

category.label: I don’t want to answer this question

question.text: Have you ever considered quitting your PhD?

category.label: I don’t want to answer this question

question.text: What was/were the reason(s) for considering to quit your PhD? (multiple answers possible)

I do not like my topic.

I do not like my working conditions.

I don’t like the social environment at my workplace.
I have personal difficulties with my supervisor.
I find my career prospective unattractive.
I do not feel qualified enough.
I have no or poor academic results.
I find other jobs more interesting.
My academic life is not compatible with my family responsibilities.
My project is not funded anymore.
I don't want to answer this question.
I experience stress/anxiety/other mental health issues.

question.text: How much do you pay for your rent and associated living costs per month in euros (e.g., heating, gas, water, and electricity)?

directive.text: Example: Your rent is 600€, you additionally pay 70€ for warm water and heating, 20€ for electricity, 20€ for internet and 10€ for garbage disposal plus elevator fees. This amounts to total costs of 720€.

category.label: I don't want to answer this question

question.text: Do you get external financial support to cover your living expenses besides your salary? If yes, who is assisting you financially (multiple answers possible)?

category.label: I do not get external financial support
I took up a loan for my time as a doctoral researcher
I don't want to answer this question

question.text: How often have you worked during weekends or public holidays in the past year?

directive.text: Please note: This question asks for work related to your PhD. It is place-independent and includes all work done at your institute/center, your home or any other location. It does not include an additional part-time job or other work which is unrelated to your PhD.

question.text: You answered 'because of other reasons' in the previous question. Please explain these other reasons for working more than your contract expects you to.
Do you know the following bodies?

subQuestion.text: The current PhD representatives at your institute

question.text: Why did you start your work on your doctoral thesis at your research center/institute (multiple answers possible)?

Interest in joining a structured PhD program/graduate school

Continuing previous scientific project (internship, Master’s thesis, etc.)

Interest in the research being carried out at the institute

question.text: In general, how satisfied are you with the following aspects of an academic research career?

subQuestion.text: Mobility (i.e., work in different countries or cities)
Compatibility of own career plans with career plans of partner
Compatibility of own career plans with having children

category.label: I don't want to answer this question

question.text: Which of the following aspects of your work as a doctoral researcher would you like to be improved?

subQuestion.text: Office equipment (e.g., computer, software, own desk etc.)

category.label: I don’t want to answer this question

question.text: Anything regarding this section you would like to tell us?

sectionInfo.text:
For the following questions, we would like to make the distinction between “formal” and “direct” supervisor clear: 

 

“Formal” supervisor refers to the main advisor of your thesis as present in your committee.

“Direct” supervisor refers to the person you actually consult and discuss your project with on a more regular basis.

 

Section 4/8

question.text: Do you have one of the following (multiple answers possible)?

directive.text:
Short Explanations:

Label                          Explanation

PhD supervision agreement          

A written agreement between the formal/primary supervisor and the doctoral researcher outlining their responsibilities from the beginning of the PhD project until the completion of the doctoral thesis.  Project outline A preliminary project plan defining the objectives of the PhD project as well as the methodology to achieve them within the given timeframe of a doctoral research project.  

Training plan     

A plan detailing the courses mandatory for the completion of your PhD. PhD guidelines   Basic rules by the MPS, standard set of recommendations of how a PhD should look like provided by the MPS. Thesis advisory committee           A thesis advisory committee or “TAC” is a group of two or more independent researchers (including your formal/primary supervisor) who you meet on a regular basis, give you advice on how to progress and successfully complete your PhD project. Graduate school                 A graduate school is an education institution, providing doctoral training, including courses and projects, for doctoral researchers in a disciplinary field.

category.label: A supervision agreement with your formal supervisor
Membership of a graduate school with the Max-Planck society (eg. IMPRS)
Membership of a different (not Max-Planck) graduate school
I don't have any of the above
I don't want to answer this question

sectionInfo.text:
In this section, we will ask questions pertaining to integration in regards to language barriers, social integration and support with administrative tasks at your [center/institute].

Section 5/8

question.text: For which of the following aspects did you receive support from your institute (multiple answers possible)?

directive.text: Explanation ‘support’: You may have received support to fulfill different administrative tasks and to give you guidance in the process. This support may have been in the form of an information document, personal e-mail or oral correspondence and has been given to you directly or at least upon request. Examples of ‘support’ can be checklists for University enrollment, visa application, or local resident registration etc.

category.label: Registering at the local Resident Registration Office
Translation of working contract and relevant documents
I don't want to answer this question

directive.text: All relevant information - This is all the information regarding your payment, weekly working hours, number of holidays per year, social security system contributions, maximum length of the contract, conditions/possibilities for contract extensions, contract goals (i.e. "submission of a dissertation"), sufficient information regarding supervision (who and to what degree), sufficient information regarding your work group (names, positions, planned length of stay at your institute).

sectionInfo.text:
In this section, we ask you about mechanisms for conflict resolution in place at your [institute/center], discrimination or conflicts you are experiencing during your PhD, for instance with a superior and your satisfaction with the resolution of these conflicts.

category.label: I have not felt discriminated in my work environment so far.

question.text: Have you ever been subject to microaggressions in your work environment?

directive.text: Microaggressions—subtle, indirect, and sometimes unintentional acts of prejudice, e.g. being complimented for having a certain quality not stereotypically associated with your identity (You’re so smart for a woman!), or being asked where you're "really" from after you already stated your home country.

category.label: I don't want to answer this question

question.text: Did you ever report a conflict with one of the following people to an official third party?

directive.text: Such an official third party for conflict reporting could be: Institute/Section Ombudsperson, Institute/General Works Council, Institute/Central Equal Opportunity officer, External law firm, PhD representatives, Compliance officer of the Max Planck Society, Medical services and counseling, Security service, Staff Unit 'Internal Investigations', the mediators at section level and EMAP. For more information, click here.

category.label: No, although I had a conflict
No, I never had any serious conflict
I don't want to answer this question

question.text: Anything regarding this section you would like to tell us?

sectionInfo.text:
In this section, we ask you about your personal, psychological well-being in the context of your doctoral research project. With this section we acknowledge the obstacles, pressure to perform, as well as the impact the latter can have on your mental health.  The term “mental health” has been explained by various scholars, but can be summarized, according to the WHO, as the "subjective well-being, perceived self-efficacy, [...] and self-actualization of one's intellectual and emotional potential, among others." 

 

The questions in this section were adapted from the “State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) and “Beck’s Depression Scale” and enable probing for the frequency of different states of mind. The occurrence of the latter is converted into a score, revealing whether or not different degrees of depression could be present. 

 

We want to, again, stress the importance of confidentiality and anonymity of the answers submitted during your participation of this survey. If you feel uncomfortable with the questions in this section, please consider replying “I don’t want to answer this question” to the questions of this section.

 

Section 8/8

Your mental health is utmost important for the success of your doctoral research project, but also for a happy and fulfilled private life. This survey aims to raise awareness amongst you, your colleagues and the scientific community. 

Please do not hesitate to turn to one of the included help lines, friends or your doctoral representatives, if especially emotionally touched by these questions.  Help lines: EMAP - Consultation Service for Employees. An external, anonymous, free service for employees and scholarship holders.  How does EMAP work? Call the phone number 0800 387 78 36 if you are in Germany or 00800 38 77 83 62 if you are abroad and give the name 'MPG'. Here you will receive support from experts who will advise you in German or English as necessary, also in other languages if the need arises.  More information for immediate help in your region can be found in this document. For more general information on mental health awarennes in PhDnet check out the following webpage. 

Connect @maxplanckphdnet

On: PhDnet | Twitter | Facebook | Instagram & website  | PhDnet Team room on MAX

Email: steering.group@phdnet.mpg.de

question.text: Please read each statement below and then indicate how you feel right now, at this moment.

category.label: I don't want to answer this question

question.text: Please read each statement below and then indicate how you generally feel.

subQuestion.text: I feel that difficulties are piling up so that I cannot overcome them
I worry too much over something that really doesn’t matter
I take disappointments so keenly that I can’t put them out of my mind

question.text: Over the last two weeks, how often have you been bothered by any of the following problems?

subQuestion.text: Little interest or pleasure in doing things
Trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much
Feeling tired or having little energy
Feeling bad about yourself - or that you are a failure or have let yourself or your family down
Trouble concentrating on things such as reading the newspaper or watching television
Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed? Or the opposite - being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual

category.label: I don't want to answer this question
